div.p: THE DEATH OF VSVRY, OR, THE DISGRACE OF VSVRERS.
COMPILED MORE PITHILY THEN HITHERTO HATH beene publiſhed in Engliſh.
Wherein Vſury is moſt lively vnfolded, defined, and confuted by Divines, Civilians, Canoniſts, Statutes, Schoole-men, old and new Writers.
With an Explanation of the Statutes now in force concerning Vſury, very profitable for this preſent Age.

q.p: Hi petunt inferos, vt diſcant verum eſſe in morte quod in vita credere noluerunt.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by I. L. for Robert Allott, and are to be ſold by Iohn Stafford, dwelling in Black-Herſe-Alley neere Fleet-ſtreet. 1634.

div.head: AVTHOƲRS AND Writers vſed in this booke beSIDES THE AVTHORITY of the holy Scriptures.
❧ VSVRA.
div.p: IT is ſo called becauſe it doth Conſtare dere.

The word Vſura is taken in two ſenſes or ſignifications:
properly.
improperly.

Properly it ſignifieth the vſe of a thing, as Eraſmus hath well obſerved, that the name of Vſurie is taken from vſing, and is to be applyed not onely to this but to all other things: the very Etymologie of the worde ſheweth it; the Latines have theſe tearmes, Vſura Solis, Vſura Lunae, Vſura Terrae, &c. Hereof M. Bullinger ſaid well, The name of vſurie is not euill, but the abuſing of it in applying it to ill trades and actions.

Improperly the name of Vſurie is ſo taken Cauſa pro effectu when we take vſurie for the increaſe and augmentation that ariſe of it, it is called vſurae of the Latiniſtes, becauſe there is received a certaine recompence for the vſe of the mony, the Graecians call it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as it were a certaine thing bred of the principall, the Haebricians call it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of biting.

There be three kindes of Vſuries,
1. Foenus naturale.
2. Foenus ſpirituale.
3. Foenus politicum.

1. Foenus naturale, is that which come and increaſe by tillage of the ground. This vſurie is lawfull, becauſe it is the ordinance of God in the beginning. Cain is called a tiller of the ground, many of our fore-fathers haue growen rich by this vſurie as Abraham, Lot, and others. It is ſo neceſſarie that no common wealth can ſtand without it; Menander doeth call the land-iuſt, becauſe in yeelding fruit it doeth the dutie of a good ground and therefore we were vniuſt if we ſhoulde not reape it.

2. Foenus ſpirituale, whereof be two ſortes,
1. Giving of Almes.
2. Imploying of Gods gifts.

Giving of Almes, is generally commended in the Scriptures, and he that giveth is as it were foenerator Domini and ſhall be well rewarded: for Salomon ſaith, he that giveth to the poore ſhall not lacke.
The imploying of the giftes and graces of God doeth yeeld in the ende a ſpirituall increaſe, and that is meant by the Talent in Matthew.

3. Foenus politicum, wherof there be alſo two ſorts,
Foenus actuale.
Foenus mentale.

Foenus actuale, is committed when one doth any act for gaine or increaſe, wherof there be two kinds
Foenus liberale.
Foenus ex pacto.

Foenus liberale, is, when he that borroweth, deſireth to make ſome recompence, the ſame which is received above the principall is Vſurie, and is not to be condemned in two reſpectes. 1. becauſe it is a duty of thankfulneſſe to make amends for a benefit received. Tully could ſay, Ingratus eſt qui gratiā bene merenti nō reponit: the Scriptures in many places condemne vnthankfulneſſe. 2. becauſe it proceedeth of the givers free-will: & volenti non fit iniuria, ſaith Tho. Aquinas: for what is more free then gift.

Foenus ex pacto, whereof there be two ſorts
vſura explicata.
vſura palliata.
Vſura explicata, is ſuch as it is indeede as when one doeth covenant to take 10. in the hundreth for a yere.
Vſura palliata, is a cloſe and cloked vſurie, as when one lendeth money and ſhroudeth it vnder ſome other bargaine.

Foenus mentale is when one lendeth and doth not compact but hopeth for increaſe or gaine. Sole hope maketh a man an vſurer ſaith one of the Canoniſtes; he that lendeth (ſaith Camiſius) vnder the hope of gaine is an Vſurer: S. Augustine vpon one of the Pſalmes ſaith, If thou doeſt but expect to reciue more then thy owne thou art an Vſurer.

div.head: VVhat Ʋſurie is.
div.p: THe civill Lawes in the Code de Vſuris doe call that Vſury which is received above the principall.
Aretius ſaith, whatſoever is taken above the principall is Vſurie.

Rodulphus ſaieth whatſoever in lending is taken above the
principall is vſurie.

D. Kimhus writing vpon the 18. of Ezek. doth ſay that vſury is expreſſed by this addition of the prophet, and receive no increaſe. This definition may ſtand ſo farre forth as it doth not condemne foenus liberale or gratuitum.
In the Decrees cap. vſur. 14 cauſ. & 3. quaeſt. that is Vſurie when more is required then was delivered or given.
Melancthon ſaith, vſurie is a gaine demaunded aboue the principall only for the pleaſure or benefit ſhewed in lending.
Conſilium Agathenſe ſay, when there is more required then is lent, that is vſurie.

This definition differ from the former, here gaine is required, there but offered or taken. And this definition doth cut off Interest, which Melancthon ſaith is a debt one owe to another by the law of nature, & it is due by the opinion of Hemingeus two manner of waies: 1. ex damno habito, 2. ex lucro ceſſante.

Ex damno habito, as when I borrow money for another and enter my bond for it, and take the like of him that receiue the mony. I may lawfully recover that I looſe by the meanes of that mony. Biſhop Iuel is of this mind alſo.

Ex lucro ceſſante, as if a ſhop-keeper lend mony freely to his neighbour till ſuch a day, having then occaſion to vſe it at ſome faire to lay it out in wares, if he breake touch the ſhop keeper may lawfully take ſo much as he ſuſtained loſſe for want of his money to lay out.

Brentius ſaith, when men require a gaine of the office of lending it is Vſurie. This definition is imperfect: for Hemingeus gives an inſtance, If I lend a marchant 100. pound vnder theſe conditions; if he gaine, I will have the moiety of the gaines: if he looſe, if it be not ex culpa larga, I am content to beare halfe the loſſe: here is gaine required of office but this contract is not offenſive.
The Divines of Wittenberge ſay, when a man require but an halfe penny or a droppe of water for the money he lendeth it is vſurie.
S. Ambroſe ſaith, that a diſh of meate, a garment, or whatſoever commeth aboue the principall is vſurie.
From the opinions and iudgements of moſt writers Actuall vſurie is thus defined.

p.hi: It is a lending for gaine by compact.

div.p: So that there doth concurre neceſſarily 3. things in this kinde of deſcribed vſurie.

There muſt be
a lending.
a lending for gaine.
a compacting for gaine.
That the truth of this may pregnantly appeare, every ſeverall point muſt of neceſsitie be prooved.

div.head: 1. Ʋſurie is a lending.
div.p: THat Vſurie is in lending it appeareth in the 22. of Exod. If thou lend mony to my people, &c. and in Deut. 23. vnto a ſtranger thou maiſt lend vpon vſurie. Bullinger intreating of this argument ſaith, that vſurie is committed only in lending. Brentius vpon Lev. 25. ſaith as much. D. Wilſon ſaith, there can be no Vſury where there is no Lending. I had thought to haue alledged that ſaying in the 6. of Luke, Lend looking for nothing againe: but that M. Bucer and M. Calvin ſay it is not meant of vſurie at all.

div.head: What Lending is.
div.p:
HEmingeus in his treatiſe vpon vſury defineth lending thus. Mutatio eſt contractus, &c. Lending is a contract which transfer the right & dominiō of a thing to another without interpoſito praetio, but with promiſe to have the ſame thing delivered
in ſpecie. As if I end a mā 100. pound for a yere, I do not only yeeld the uſe but the propertie of it, only to haue that I lend in the ſame kind without gaine, or if I lend oyle or wine or any thing ſubiect to lending (which be ſuch things as conſiſt in Waight, Nomber, and Meaſure) I muſt obſerve the like courſe; yet Heſiodus ſpeaking hereof willeth the borrower to deliver iuſt meaſure & amplius ſiquidem poſsis that he may finde his neighbour ready to pleaſure him againe ſi alias indigeas, or as Heming. ſaith, pertinebit ad gratitudinem. The Latines make a difference betweene Mutatio and Accommodatio, when any doth mutuum dare he lookes but for his owne in eadem specie, but when he doth Accommodare he lookes to receive it in individuo, as if he lends his horſe to haue the ſame againe and not an other, or if he lets his houſe, to haue the ſame, and none other.

div.head: 2. Ʋſurie is a lending for gaine.
div.p: THat vſury is a lending for Gaine it appeareth by the prophets repetition: Thou hast taken vſurie & the increaſe, Ezek. 22.12. this worde increaſe, is as much as gaine? as when a man lendeth 10. pound & take 11. pound: or 20 combs barley and take 22. for a yere, he hath not incrementum ex vſu. S. Ambroſe commends him to be a good man that doth lend and take no increaſe. Nehemiah did lend corne, and mony to his brethren without looking for gaine.

div.head: What it is to lend for gaine.
div.p:
GAbriel Biel ſaith, that gaine is the increaſe of mony, or the value of any thing that may be prized and meaſured for
money. Whoſoeuer lendeth his money, corne, wine, oyle, and receiue any thing for the vſe of it, is an Vſurer. S. Ambroſe and Hierome ſay there are many that will not take money, but certaine other gifts, this is Vſurie: whatſoeuer it be they receiue more then they lend, it is Vſurie, Muſc. 579. Moſt writers condemne him which take money or monies worth for lending. Hemingeus giueth ſome inſtances; one man borrowes a hundreth pounds and offereth vſe for it, the lender refuſe to take it, but tels him if he will beſtow a gowne-cloth of his wife, or the paſturing of a horſe, or ſome of S. Austens workes, or ſuch like, he will let him haue his money, this is Vſurie though it be cloaked.

div.head: 3. Vſurie is a lending for gaine by Compact.
div.p: THat there is a compacting for Gayne, it appeareth Exod. 22. the Lord ſaith, Non impone vſuram, &c. thou ſhalt not impoſe vſurie vpon thy brother, by which appeare to be a kinde of compact. M. Beza tearmes him to be foenerator pacti, which take or exact any thing by lending, hereof the Statute made in anno 11. Henr. 7. chap. 8. did forbid vſurie of contract or couenant.

div.head: VVhat it is to Compact.
div.p:
THe Civilians tearme that a Compact, when as two men or
moe, doe conferre and conſent together of a matter.

The Lawyers ſay there are two kinde of Compacts:
Pactum tacitum.
Pactū expreſſum.

Pactum tacitum is this, when as conſent or agreement is intended; an inſtance hereof appeares in Numb. 30. as when the parents of two children doe debate of a mariage betweene their children, the children ſtand by and heare all, but ſay nothing, by ſilence in the children intenditur conſenſus. Silence is many times to be taken as an anſwer betweene the Vſurer and the borower: as for example, if a man comes to an Vſurer to borrowe money, and tels him he will allow him after ten in the 100. although the vſurer ſaith nothing, this is a kinde of compact: or if one comes to borrowe money, and the vſurer ſaith he will take after ten in the 100, albeit the borrower ſaith nothing, but takes the money, it is a kinde of Compact: and it is ſo vſuall, that M. Bucer ſaith, he is counted an impudent man that doth not offer vſurie.

Pactum expreſſum is either
Nudum.
Veſtitum.

Nudum, the bare compact is, when one comes to borrowe money, the vſurer asketh him if he will giue vſe for it, the borrower ſaith he will, this is ſo called, becauſe the vſurer depends vpon the borrower what he will giue.

Veſtitum, the certen or ſhrouded compact, is either in
Verbis.
Scriptis.
In verbis, when the borrower paſſeth his promiſe for the payment of vſe.
In ſcriptis, when the vſurer takes ſpecialty for the vſe of his money.

div.head: How farre Vſurie extendeth.
div.p: VSurie is not onely cloked, but alſo committed as well in many other things as in money, and therefore the Lorde doth not onely condemne vſurie of money, but alſo vſurie of meate, vſurie of any thing is put to vſurie, Deut. 23.19.

S. Hierome ſaith, ſome ſuppoſe there is no vſurie but in money. This did the holy Scriptures foreſee, which take away increaſe in all other things. M. Bullinger ſaith, that vſurie is committed in the vſe of cattell, houſe and ground.
Hemingeus ſaith, that vſurie is committed in lending of all things, and doth hide it ſelfe vnder diuers kind of contracts, as buying, ſelling, lending, letting, exchanging, giuing to paune, &c.
By the opinion of the Schoolemen, vſurie is taken ſo largely that it comprehendeth buying and ſelling.

M. Calvin ſaith, Multi contractus ab hominibus vafris excogitati ſunt, quibus inopes expilarent, ſine ignominia vel dedecore, atque hodie nulla crudelior eſtir apacitas quàm vbi ab ſque mentione foenoris vectigal debitoribns imponitur. Calvin. in Harmo.

So that this generally toucheth Merchants, Shop-keepers, Corne-mongers, and all others that haue any trading and traffique in the common-weale. Yet we muſt take heede that we doe not condemne all profitable and lawfull contracts, as Hemingeus ſaith, praetextu vſurae propter ſimilitudinem: for that in no wiſe is iuſt; no contract is to be condemned qui charitati proximi non aduerſatur.
Sithence vſurie is committed in ſo many things, it weare neceſſarie to knowe ſome of the greateſt vſuries that the worſe might haue his appearance.

div.head: Ʋ Ʋhich is the greateſt Ʋſurie.
div.p: IF our Vſurie in money were all one with that of the Iewes, the queſtion were ſoone anſwered: for they tooke after 60.70.80. in the 100. It appeares in Graftons Chronicle that about the yeere of our Lord 1264. and in the 47. yeere of the raigne of Henry the 3. King of England, fiue hundreth Iewes were ſlaine by the Citizens of London, becauſe one Iewe would haue forced a Chriſtian man to pay more then two pence for the vſurie of twentie ſhillings the weeke: as for our vſurie in money after the rate of 10. in the 100. it comes not to an halfe-penny a weeke for twentie ſhillings: and therefore I take it to be the leaſt vſurie that is vſed this day in the land.

div.head: 1. Wares and Marchandize.
div.p: HE that puts forth money dare not exceede the rate of 10. in the 100. but he that vttereth ware doth make his rate to his owne contentment. In money they reſt vpon the conſcience of the borrower what he will beſtow (for our laws allow nothing for vſe:) In ware they vſe their owne diſcretions in taking what they can get.

In money there may not be taken after 10. in the hundred, but within the time without trebble loſſe in ware they care not
what they gaine, nor howe ſoone they make ſale, ſo they may take money.

In money, the allowance is ſeene and knowne to others after 10. in the 100. In wares, the gaynes that are got be ſecret and concealed to them ſelues. One will not let to boaſt he hath ſaued aboue 30. in the 100. when the other durſt not ſay he hath taken aboue 10. in the 100. for money.
It is ordinarie with occupyers to proportion the price of their wares according to the time of payment as well as vſurers.
Many occupyers will often vſe theſe ſhifts whereof they haue no vſe in money.
They will mixe their wares if they be ill with better, if good with worſe, and ſo by chopping both away togither deceiue the buyer.

They will giue bad meaſure, and vſe falſe waights, whereof the Prophet Micah complaineth, Are yet the treaſures of wickednes in the houſe of the wicked and the ſcant meaſure that is abhominable, ſhall I iuſtifie the wicked ballances and the bagge of deceitfull waights, Micah 6.10, 11.

To ſet a fayre gloſſe for gayne of their counterfeit ware, they will vſe Lying and Swearing, they are ſo carried with the ſauour of gayne, that they make no conſcience of a lye, but as the Prophet ſaith, They haue taught their mouthes to lye. Ier. 9.5. and that they may be the better beleeued when they lye, they will vſe ſwearing; for cuſtome hath made it ſo common that they thinke periurie no impietie but worldly pollicie, and therfore it is true the ſame Prophet ſaith, As a cage is full of birds, ſo are there houſes full of deceit, thereby they are become great and waxen rich, Ier. 5.27.

div.head: 2. Corne or Grayne.
div.p: HE that puts out an 100. pound for a yeere, may not take aboue 10. pound for the lone, albeit the borrower may peraduenture gayne aboue 30. or 40. pound with the money, but he that laieth out 100. pound in Corne doth ſometime gaine aboue 50. yea ſometime 100. in the 100. for not long ſince the price of Corne ſo increaſed, that neceſsitie willed many rather to pay the penaltie of their bonds, then to make deliuerie of their bargains; hereupon ſome vnreaſonable Corn-mongers, Malſtars, and ſuch like were grieued becauſe they tooke no bils, as diſcontent of double gaines by their bonds.

It is a common practiſe in this countrey, if a poore man come to borrow money of a Malſter, he wil not lend any, but tels him if he will ſell ſome barley he will giue him after the order of fore-hand buyers, the man beeing driuen to diſtreſſe, ſels his corne farre vnder foote, that when it comes to be deliuered he looſeth halfe in halfe, oftentimes double the value.
I haue heard many of theſe fore-hand ſellers ſay, that they had rather allowe after 20. pound in the 100. for money, then to ſell theſe fore-hand bargaines of corne.

Theſe are moſt extreame Vſuries, and they haue no colour to excuſe it, but a reaſon of Gabriell Byel: for that the price of Corne is caſuall in riſing and falling: this is ſoone anſwered, howſoeuer it may ſeeme caſuall at the buying, the commoditie being deliuered, it is certen at the receipt, and therefore this can be no excuſe to warrant exceſsiue gayne.

div.head: Malſters and Cornemongers may vſe more deceit then Mony-maſters.
div.p: IF money be not put forth there come no increaſe by keeping of it, that appeares in the idle ſeruant by the Talent, but they cannot be content to make preſent ſale of their corne for a reaſonable price, but many doe hoard and keepe their corne of purpoſe to inhaunce the price, and ſo oppreſſe the poore, as the Prophet (ſpeaking in their perſon) ſaith, That we may buy the poore for ſiluer, and the needie for ſhoes, Amos 8.8. and by keeping of it they doe not onely raiſe the price, but impaire the corne, making it vnſauorie at the ſale: therefore in the ſame place it followes, Yea and ſell the refuſe of wheate.

In money they cannot be deceiued of their iuſt ſome, if they haue their ſight, but in Corne they will abridge the meaſure many waies by deceit, when one leaſt ſuſpects, or can beſt ſee, which the Prophet well perceiued: for he ſaith that they make the Ephah ſmall, and the ſhekell great, and falſifie the waights by deceit, Amos 8.5.
In money they may not exceede the rate of 10. in the 100. In corne they gaine by buying, and by giuing day in the ſale to others they will gayne by the time.
Aristotle ſaith well, foenus est quaſi foetus: for I take this to be one of the moſt extreame Vſuries in the land. Therefore M. Calvin ſaith, Vſura nihilo deterior erit quam emptio. in 8. praec. 375.

div.head: 3. Lands and Tenements.
div.p: THere are ſome that hire houſe and lande after 20. pound the yeare, and are good gayners by it, and yet they let the ſame to others and make after 60. pound the yeare, this caſe is too common.
I haue knowne others that haue laid out ſome 800. pound in purchaſe, and in leſſe ſpace then a yeere haue ſold the ſame again for 1100. to another and readie payment.

I note theſe but by the way, but indeede if we would knowe the reaſon why Corne, Cattell, and ſuch other commodities are ſo deare at this day, more then in other times before paſſed, we ſhall finde this to be the cauſe; the racking and vnreaſonable rents of houſe and lande: for it is nowe come to this paſſe, that Farmars can not afford their commodities at indifferent prizes, for if they ſhould, their extreame rents would inforce them to runne away.

The Rents of houſe and land are almoſt come to the rates of money, which is very vnreaſonable if but in this reſpect, becauſe Landes are immooueable and certen, but money is ſubiect to many caſualties and aduentures, as ſhall appeare vpon the handling hereafter of the Statute 13. Elizabeth.

To ſpeake generally of all kinds of vſurie were too tedious, but theſe may giue a light to the reſt, notwithſtanding this is to be noted as an vniuerſall obſeruation, that he which hath but 100. pound, and puts it forth, ſhall hardly maintaine his family with the lone of 10. pound, & yet many an one maintaineth him
ſelfe and his charge with leſſe then 40. pound by imploying the ſame in trading and traffique in other things.
If the Lord will not permit any Vſury in money, much leſſe will he ſuffer others in their ſeverall callings to exact vnreſonable gaine: for he doth not onely forbid one but the other. Deut. 23.

div.head: How and in what ſort Ʋſurie is condemned by the word of God.
div.p:
THere be many places of proofe for this purpoſe, ſome whereof follow.
Exodus. 22.
Levitic. 25.
Deuter. 23. and
Pſalm. 15.
Prov. 28.
Ezek. 18. & 22. Some adde theſe
Pſal. 55.
Pſal. 72

The whole Law is divided into three parts
Morall.
Iudiciall.
Ceremoniall.

It is much diſputable among writers which of theſe three ſhould apprehend Vſurie; it were in vaine here to expreſſe their variable opinions: but I will briefly deliver the iudgemēts of the learneder ſort.
The matter of vſurie is Politicall or Iudiciall.

So ſay
M. Calvin in
Octav. praeceptum. 375.
Harmon. in Exod. Levit. &c.
Philip. Melancthon in Epitom. Philoſophiae moralis.
Danaeus Aethic. ſuper praecep. octav. and many others.
That we are not tyed to the Iewes Policies or Iudicial lawes,

Appeares by
M Calvin. in Institut. lib. 4. cap. 20. ſect. 15.16.
D. Pet. Martyr. ſup. 1. lib. Samu. cap. 25. ſect. 42.
M. Beza. in decima Epiſtola, and many others.

So that from hence is to be obſerved, that the approbation, diſprobation, tolleration, and moderation of Vſurie, depend vpon the Magiſtrate. Hereof ſaieth M. Calvin, The Vſurer muſt take heede that he exceede not that rate of the Countrey where he liveth. Bullinger ſaith, The Magiſtrate muſt keepe the Vſurer in with good lawes. Labother is of that opinion. Zwinglius de dupl. Iuſtic. ſaith, I thinke of Vſurie thus, when the lawes of a Magiſtrate doe permit it, it may be vſed, but if the Magiſtrate forbid it, it muſt of all ſortes be obeyed. Hemingeus is of that mind.

div.head: Lawes made aginst Ʋſurie.
div.p: THe Emperour Leo did make a Law againſt vſurie that whatſoever any man did take, ſhoulde be received into the principall. Hermenopol. lib. 3. tit. 7.
Pope Martin in the counſell he called did forbid Vſury, and centeſimam vſuram, and that gaine which was got by any filthy trade. Ex concil. Ma. Papa.
Pope Leo did likewiſe forbid the ſame as ſorry any Chriſtian man ſhould be an vſurer.
In the Synod of Nicen, wherein were aſſembled three hundred and eighteene fathers, in a Canon they made did condemne all vſurie. in Decret. 47.
There were many decrees to forbid vſurie in the Clargie.
If he did put out money to vſurie he ſhould be none of the Clargie. 33. d. Martis d. 46. ſeditio.
If he tooke 12. in the 100. more or leſſe he ſhould be degraded and made irreguler. Concil. Nicen. 18.

There were Canons made for the Laiety, being an vſurer he was
ſuſpended from the Communion.
excōmunicated out of the church.
not capable to make a will of his goods.
not to be admitted to Chriſtian buriall.
Yea, the Canon Lawe ſaith, No man need to care what become of an vſurer.

div.head: Lawes made to moderate Ʋſurie.
div.p: SOlon made a law among the Athenians and he did allowe de centum aureis ſingulis menſibus aureus vnus. Heming.
The Romane Emperour Iuſtinius ordeined a law in his time for the tollerating of 4.6.8.12. in the 100. according to the degrees of men. Heming.
Tully maketh mention in his time of another Lawe, how at the firſt there was graunted 1. in the 100. afterward 4. in the 100.
The Civill lawes in the Code de vſuris doe permit the hundred and halfe hundred part.
By the law of Pandect and Constantine, Vſury is tollerated in ſome ſort.

div.head: Statutes and Lawes made by Kings and Governours within this land concerning Vſurie.
div.p: IN and before the Raine of King Henry 3. the Lawes for Vſury did conſiſt in the holy Canons of the Church and were puniſhable by them. I read of Iuſtinius the Emperour how in his Conſtitution he did ordaine that the holy Canons of the Church ſhould haue power and authoritie againſt the Lawes of Vſury.
Theſe Lawes being ſo ſtraight and generall, the ſaide King Henry in the 20. yeere of his raigne cap. 5. did make this proviſo for the benefit of Orphans only.

p.hi: IT is provided and granted by the King that from henceforth vſuries ſhall not turne againſt any being within age from the time of the death of his Aunceſtour (whoſe heire he is) vnto his lawfull age. So nevertheleſſe that the payment of the principall debt with the vſurie that was before the death of his auncestour (whoſe heire he is) ſhall not remaine.

div.p: Muſculus ſaith, that our predeceſſours vſed the order of pupils and orphans before the peſtilent plague of Vſurie had prophaned and defiled the Church, and were contented to permit that in them, and in none elſe.
It appeareth by this braunch that all Vſury is condemned ſave in orphans.

div.head: 14. Edward. 3. Chap. 5.
div.p: KIng Edward made this Lawe. The King and his heires ſhall have the Conuſance of Vſurers dead, and the ordinaries of holy Church ſhall have the Conuſance of vſurers on liefe as to them appertaineth to make compulſion by the Cenſures of the holy Church for the ſinne to make reſtitution of the vſuries taken against the lawes of holy Church.
This is the firſt law at large that I can finde for Vſurie in the Statutes ſince Magnacarta, wherein all vſury is generally condemned.

div.head: 3. Henry. 7. Chap. 5.6.
div.p: THis King made a ſtrict law, eſpecially for theſe damnable bargaines of vſury coloured by the name of new cheniſance, ſuch as dealt corruptly in it were to pay an hundred pound. Alſo if any man did lend 100. pound and tooke 120. more or leſſe in money or marchandiſe &c. was to looſe his principall. Here hee condemned all vſurie, but in the 11. yeere of his raigne chap. 8. he repealed the former act and inacted an other to this effect.

All maner of perſon or perſons lending monie to and for a time, taking for the ſame lone, any thing more beſides or above the money lent by vvay of contract or covenant at the time of
the ſame lone (ſaving lawfull penalties for default of paiment) was to forfeit the moiety or one halfe of the principall there be other branches therein concerning corruption by way of cheniſance, &c.

I obſerve from this how no vſurie is condemned but that which is impoſed vpon the borrower by way of contract or covenant at the time of the lending, if there were no contracting for gaine there was no breach of the Lawe, ſo that the borrower was not barred by this, but that he might gratifie the lender at his owne election.

div.head: 37. Henry. 8. Chap. 9.
div.p: KIng Henry repealed all the Lawes and ſtatutes made concerning vſurie before, and doeth enact, that if any man take above 10. in the 100. for a yere or more or leſſe money after that rate, he ſhould looſe treble the value of the ſumme lent, it is ſo likewiſe in cheniſance and wares, divers other clauſes and branches be therein.

This Statute is intituled an act againſt vſurie, it doth not perſwade any to take Vſury, but reſtraine him to certaine orders, the husbandman ſuffereth many weedes to grow in his ground he likes not, ſo this law doth tolerate that it allowes not, it remits men of puniſhment that take but 10. in the 100. but it doeth not warrant them to take any at all. Therefore M. Beza well noted, that the civill lawes of Princes by reaſon of the impiety of the people are often times tollerated when they cannot be taken away.

div.head: 5. & 6. Edward. 6.
div.p: KIng Edvvard repealed the former act of King Henry 8. and forbiddeth generally all vſurie. He that tooke any ſhould not onely looſe the principall with the vſe, but alſo be puniſhed with impriſonment and make fine and ranſome at the Kings pleaſure.

The common ſaying is, ſome will take an ell where is given an inch: that liberty which that man of famous memory, King Henry 8. gave was abuſed, therefore his ſonne to avoid an inconvenience did cut off the occaſion: but as water being pent doth ſtrive more vpward, ſo the vſurer being reſtrained he waxed worſe, and therefore this Statute of King Edvvard continued not long.

Of all theſe Statutes before mentioned none remaine in force, but ſome of the braunches of the Statute of K. Henry 8. now I think it very neceſſary to handle more copiouſly ſome of thoſe particular and ſpeciall clauſes which be included in the laſt act againſt vſurie as a matter very expedient to be publiſhed, that many which knowe not how farre it extende may thereby avoid many extremities.

div.head: 13. Elizabeth Reg. Chap. 8.
div.p:
OVr gratious Queene Elizabeth repealed the former act of her brother K. Edw. 6. and doth revive the Statute of
K. Henry 8. in this ſort, that (whereas it is the honour of Engliſh lawes to be favourable) the acte of K. Henry ſhould be moſt largely and ſtrongly conſtrued to the repreſsing of vſury and puniſhing offenders therein.
In the reſt of that Statute which is now in moſt force there be 4. clauſes or braunches moſt ſpecially and neceſſarily to be noted and explaned.

div.head: 1. Braunch.
All bondes and contractes &c. for money or other things whereupon ſhall be reſerved or taken above 10. in the 100, ſhall be void, &c.
div.p:
This is a dangerous clauſe in two reſpects, & may happen to a man
1. by his owne fault.
2. by the negligēce of others.
If a man for grippleneſſe will reſerve more then 10. in the 100. although he never takes it his principall is loſt. And this I deeme his owne fault.

If the writer deceiue a man in the making or dating of a bond, without the lenders privitie, his mony is loſt although he had no ſuch meaning. And this may happen to many a ſimple man through the negligence of others.

div.head: 2. Braunch.
He that takes above 10. in the 100. for mony, wares, &c. ſhall forfeit thriſe as much, beſides impriſonment, fine, and Eccleſiaſticall correction.
div.p:
There is difference betweene reſerving and taking Vſurie, he that reſerues it, neede not take it vnleſſe he will, but if he take it,
he is ſure of that he reſerued: it is a leſſer ſinne to promiſe, then performe ill, and a leſſe hurt to reſerue, then to take Vſurie: therfore this clauſe is more ſtraight then the former. A man may hazard himſelfe and his goods herein many waies.
1. If a man takes aboue 10. pound in the 100. directly, he is conuicted by this branch.
2. If a man takes aboue 10. pound in the 100. indirectly, he is in great daunger.
Indirect taking, is many waies to be taken: but I will note 2. eſpecially.
The taking of money but a day leſſe then a yeere, may indanger one, &c.

There was one indebted to an Vſurer in a great ſome of money, the borrower dwelling farre off, came a day or two before his day of payment, and (with a friend of his) requeſted the Vſurer to take his money, ſaying that he came farre, and was at charges, and therefore would gladly giue him his whole allowance; after many intreaties the Vſurer tooke his money, but the borrower procured him a trebble miſchiefe afterward.

He that takes but 10. pound in the 100. in money, and the borower beſtows ſome other gift of him, I cannot ſee how ſafely the Vſurer may take it without offence to the Law, if the borrower be not the better man. I heard it credibly reported of one that lent 200. pound to two men for a yere; the day being expired, and they vnprouided to pay the money, brought not onely the conſideration, but to perſwade the lender to let them haue the money an other yeare, they would needs inforce vpon him as a free gift a gown-cloath which he refuſed, neuertheleſſe vſing apt perſwaſions, that they had gained greatly by the mony, at length by their importunitie, he tooke it, but how he was vſed afterward by the meanes of theſe men which gaue the gift, it were too odious to open. It were pitie that the othe of a borrower
ſhould be any way beneficiall to himſelfe about the thing he borrowes, there are many will not ſticke to beſtow an othe if their creditours doe but croſſe them, or call for their owne.
3. One miſtaken worde of a writer, or falſe othe of a borrower, may hazard a man herein.

div.head: 3. Braunch.
He that takes aboue 10. in the 100. for money or wares, ſhall forfeit ſo much as ſhall be reſerued by way of vſurie, &c.
div.p: THis branch is more fauourable then the former for two cauſes.
1. Becauſe the Vſurer ſhall be puniſhed but with the loſſe of that he receiue without perill of the principall.
2. Becauſe he ſhall haue no temporall or eccleſiaſticall correction, though he looſe that which he taketh aboue the principall, ſo it be but, or vnder 10. in the 100.

When K. Henry 8. did tollerate 10. pound in the 100. many abuſed that libertie vnder the colour of the Law, and when K. Edward 6. had vtterly taken away all vſurie, this inconvenience came, fewe or none would lend becauſe they might haue no allowance, whereupon her Maieſtie to auoyde this euill, made this remiſsiue clauſe.

This Braunch doth allowe no Vſurie at all, but doth leaue it after a ſort to the curteſie and conſcience of the borrower: for as the Lawe doth conuict no man without proofe, or take knowledge of this offence without information, ſo it is to be preſumed, that none can ſo fitly be an approouer as he that findeth himſelfe grieued, which of neceſsitie muſt be the borrower becauſe he payeth the vſurie.
The borrower hath this libertie by this branch for his owne benefit.

list.item: 1. If hee promiſe vſurie, he neede not to pay it vnleſſe he will.
2. If he pay vſurie, he may recouer it againe if he be grieued.
3. If he be willing to pay vſurie, he is at his owne choice to complaine.

div.p: Moſt of theſe common, or rather cunning Vſurers, are come to this paſſe, becauſe the law alloweth no vſurie, they will put in no vſe in their bonds, but leaue it to the courteſie of the borrower, if he giueth vſe they will take it, if none, they will note him another time when he ſtandes in neede, and for this cauſe, becauſe they are doubtfull of mens dealings, they will not put forth their money aboue 3. moneths, that the borower can hardly make any profitable returne of it in ſo ſhort time.

div.head: 4. Braunch.
This Statute doth not extend nor ſhalbe expounded to extend vnto any allowances or payments for the finding of Orphanes according to the auncient rates or cuſtomes of London, &c.
div.p: IT is a godly act, that thoſe ſhould be prouided for that cannot prouide for themſelues; the Scripture willeth that the fatherleſſe ſhould be prouided for. K. Hen. 3. K. Hen. 8. and our gratious Queene Elizabeth, haue for good cauſes graunted and continued this allowance: their allowance is 5. in the 100. which Hemingeus prooues to be lawfull, becauſe it doth not fall into the contract of Vſurie: his reaſon is this, Nam nec tutores de alieno obligantur mutuare, nec qui mutuum accipiunt, vbi nulla, nec diuina, nec naturalis praeceſsit obligatio ſeu debitum, iuſtè gratitudinem pro accepto beneficio recuſare poſſunt.
There is great reaſon why allowance may be graunted to orphanes, and not to men.

Men haue wit and diſcretion to imploy their money in many things, though they lend not vpon Vſurie. With their money they may buy houſe and land, and ſaue by a reaſonable rent, or wares, and make a reaſonable gaine, or come or cattell, or other commodities, and reape a reaſonable commoditie.
The orphan as he is yong in yeares, ſo he is in diſcretion, and wants that fore-ſight in trading & traffique in the world, which experience of more yeares may bring at mans eſtate.

But it may be obiected, that the orphans money may be imploied
by an other, ſome other way then by allowance, ſo it may be alledged, vnleſſe the tutor or gouernour be an honeſt man, it will neuer be improoued, but he may impaire it vnder colour of many loſſes without iuſt cauſe, and ſo defeate the pore orphan of his portion, therefore very conuenient is this proviſo; for whatſoeuer gayne is got by the orphans money by others, yet the orphan ſhall be ſure to haue ſome allowance towards his education during his noneage, and his ſtocke to be ſafe at mans eſtate for his maintenance.

I haue dilated this whole Statute for two cauſes:
1. The knowledge of the ignorant.
2. The benefit of the Vſurer.

There be many ſimple men which hauing no inſight into this Statute, are not aſhamed to ſay that it alloweth 10. in the 100. which indeede is a meere ſcandall and ſlaunder: for it inflicteth a kinde of puniſhment, by the loſſe of the leaſt Vſurie that is taken: therefore ſuch as be ignorant of this Statute may now know it.

The Vſurer may ſee by this Statute, how many aduentures he is ſubiect to by lending his money to Vſurie; although he doth not quoad eventum like the husbandman that ſoweth his ſeede, or the merchant that croſſe the ſeas, aduenture: yet for all he doth quoad media vſe all the beſt meanes to ſaue his owne, he may be intercepted, and therefore he may learne to imploy his money otherwiſe to his benefit as well as others, and albeit his gaynes be greater many waies therein then after 10. in the 100. it wilbe leſſe noted, and himſelfe better eſteemed.
The chiefe ende I aymed at in the diſtribution of this Statute is, to draw an argument from the ſame to this effect,

p.hi: Thoſe which write and speake most for Vſurie, ſay it depends vpon the poſitiue Law of the land.
But the poſitiue Law of our land admits no Vſurie, but allowance for orphans.
Therefore no Vſurie may be taken of any but allowance for orphans.

div.head: Whether Ʋſurie may be taken of Rich-men.
div.p: MAny are of the opinion that Vſurie may be taken of the Rich without offence to the word of God, by permiſſion of the Magiſtrate.

M. Calvin writing vpon that place in the 22. of Exod. If thou lend money to my people, that is, to the porre with thee, thou ſhalt not be as an Vſurer to him, maketh this expoſition: Non niſi de pauperibus haberi ſermonem, ideo
que ſi cum diuitibus negotium ſit, liberum ius foenerandi permitti: his reaſon is this, Quia legiſlator rem vnam notando, alter am de qua ſubticet, videtur non damnari, he ſaith by all neceſſarie conſequence, the expreſſe and ſpeciall prohibition of the poore by name, doth giue an intended and intellectual permiſsion to others: inſomuch as he flatly affirmeth in another place vſuras quaſlibet abſque exceptione damnare nulla patitur ratio. octa. prae. 375.
M. Bucer giues many inſtances to this effect, which for brevitie I will omit.
Hemingeus approoues this kinde of vſurie euen from the very lawe of lending: for he ſaith, Indigentibus ſolis gratuita mutuatio debetur: & non auaritiae inſatiabili ſervire debet.

Euery contract which in his kind or by circumſtances ought to be free, if there be a compact to receiue any thing beſides the
principall eſt Vſurarius contractus, & properly this is called Vſurie. Gerſonis regula. From hence Hemingeus ſaith, non eſſe vſurarium cōtractum, which by circumſtances ought to be free. The free contract of lending concernes the poore, but if the Rich borrow, he ſaith, dico Vſuram hic propriè non committi propterea quod beneficium iſtud fuit liberum ad quod nec diuino nec natur ali iure eras obligatus: and in another place he ſaith, Quid enim peccat qui pro beneficio expectat gratitudinem, and affirmeth that it is naturall equitie, that for a good turne quod non iure debemus another be done, that there may be equalitie.

That the libertie may appeare to be lawfull for vſurie of the Rich, you ſhall heare the learned opinions of ſome vpon the 15. Pſalme. Lord, who ſhall dwell in thy Tabernacle? He that hath not giuen forth vpon Vſurie.

M. Calvin ſaith, that the name of Neſeck which Dauid vſeth, beeing deriued of byting, declareth ſufficiently that vſurers are condemned ſo farre forth as they draw with them a libertie to pill and poll. In another place he ſaith, Si obijciant foeneratores à Davide & Ezech. in totum damnari, ſententias illas ad normam charitatis exigi debere arbitror: ideo
que non damnari niſi improbas exactiones, quibus creditor, poſthabita aequitate, debitorem ſuum oner at, ac premit.

D. AEpinus writing vpon the 15. Pſal. doth name 3. kindes of men, Mendicantium, Indigentium, & eorum qui ſunt Locupletes, and after he hath learnedly and largely handled the matter, he concludes thus, in tertio or dine non committi vſuram.

Hemingeus vpon the 15. Pſal. ſaith, that it is manifeſt that the Pſalmiſt doth there ſpeake of biting vſurie, becauſe he doth vſe this word Neſeck. quod à mor ſu nomen habet: further he ſaith, that in this Pſalme is forbidden but that vſurie quae ante in Moſe fuit interdicta, and this is his reaſon, Prophetae enim nullam nouam doctrinam afferunt ſed tantum Moſis ſunt Interpretes. fol. 958.

S. Augustin hath a ſenſible ſaying, where things are more plainly vttered in the Scripture, there muſt we learne how they are to be vnderſtoode in obſcure and darke places. Auguſt. lib. 83. quaeſt. from hence ſome frame a reaſon thus;

If all parts of the Scripture expound one an other (as they doe by the opinion of Chryſoſtome 2. Gen. homil. 13.) then ye muſt conſider, that as all riuers runne they neuer ſo crooked, haue recourſe from the fountaine as the head, ſo all future places of proofe concerning vſurie, ſeeme they neuer ſo obſcure, haue reference and doe rely vpon the former, which M. Calvin and Hemingeus haue expounded before to concerne the poore.

Theſe learned men are to be reuerenced for their opinions, becauſe they reconcile themſelues after a ſort in their owne ſayings: for whatſoeuer they approoue in particular & reſpectiuely for vſurie, they condemne generally by their concluſion.
M. Calvin ſaith, Praeceptum mutuandi abſque foenore, politicum eſt, and doth no further allow of vſurie then the lawe of the Magiſtrate permitteth.
Hemingeus prooues ſome vſurie lawfull, but how? ſi ſervatur aequalit as quam Magiſtratus ſtatuit.
D. AEpinus though he ſaith in tertio ordine non committi vſuram, yet he addeth this, modo alioqui ab aequalitate non decedatur, which is to be appointed by the Magiſtrate.
Theſe men doe no further defend vſurie then they referre their iudgements to the law of the Magiſtrate, we hauing no law to approoue it, their opinions are ſatisfied.

div.head: Certaine reaſons why ſome rich men ought not to borrow vpon Vſurie.
div.p:
What ſhould mooue a Rich man to borow mony, hath he not
corne to make mony of, yet he perceives that markets are litle worth, and therefore he doth reſerve it to that ende the Iewes did at Ieruſalem, Amos 8. to make a dearth, and not as Ioſeph did in Egypt to relieve the famiſhed.
Another hath great ſtore of cattell, and may ſell ſome of them for money, but it may be, that cattell beare no price, or his grounds be vnderſtored.

Many haue divers other things which they may well forbeare and ſell in reſpect of any want which they doe ſpare and reteine vpon ſome covetous fore-caſts: for they preſume they ſhall looſe leſſe by allowing after ten in the 100. for money, then by preſent ſale of any of their cōmodities at thoſe ordinary prices.
Rich-men I confeſſe may ſomtime want money and borrow for good and neceſſary conſiderations, but moſt commonly what cauſe doth conſtraine moſt of them to borrow? alas, it is lamentable to expreſſe.

One ſeeth an houſe and ground of his neighbours that were fit to be laid to his owne, he will vſe all the meanes that may be to have it, (as Ahab did by Naboth hee would needes have his peece of ground to make him a garden, becauſe it was neere his houſe 1. King. 21.2.) if he wants mony to purchaſe it, he will take it vp at Vſans.

Another hath entred into a great purchaſe which hath a common appendant to it for the benefite of the poore, which he meanes to aprone to his owne vſe (a thing too common in theſe daies:) the Prophet could ſee this in his time: for he ſaith, They covet fieldes, and take them by violence: and houſes, and take them away, ſo they oppreſſe a man and his houſe. Micah. 2.2. If he wants money to wade through withall, he will non ſticke to viſit the vſurer

There be others which be the cormorants of a Commonweale that borrow mony of purpoſe to buy corne, to hoord it
vp to inhaunce the price, to ſhip it away to make it ſcarſe, vſing all pollicie againſt Gods providence to make a famine and thereby procure the curſes of the poore, Prov. 28.

There be others that borrow mony to conſume in prodigall maner, in bravery, banketting, voluptuous living, & ſuch like: they conſume that in waſt which many poore doth want, the coſtly apparell on their backs do ſo ſtick in the mercers bookes, and the dainty cates for their bellies, doth ſo ſoake their purſes, and the riotous company they keepe is ſuch a moath to their mony that they are inforced through folly to reſort to the vſurer as their beſt friend, and very glad are they if they may get mony: though they obtaine it by pawning their iewels, plate, or landes.

If any of theſe or others like theſe do borrow mony for theſe or the like purpoſes. He that doth lend them any doth procure a great miſchiefe, or if he hath any foreknowledge of it or ſuſpicion of ſuch a pretence, he is partaker of the ſinne and curſe whereof the borrower is culpable. Heming. ſaith, we ought not to lend to ſuch neither by divine, natural, or humane law, which do abuſe mony to theirs and others deſtructions, his reaſons followes. Nam qui occaſionem damni dedit, damnum dediſſe videtur, quamobrem fit reus alieni peccati ac ſiſiuum proprium onus ſibi non ſatis eſſet. And it appeareth in the Roman. 1.31. that not onely the followers but ſuch as were favourers and furtherers of evill were reprooved and puniſhed.

This inconvenience hath growen by reaſon of lending to the Rich, ſince they began to borow the law of free-lendidg to the poore hath bin laid aſide: for it is now come to this paſſe that the poore man ſhall ſooner begge then borrow, becauſe the Vſurer thinke all loſt that is lent to him, or litle to be got by lending vnto him. He that will lend to the rich to ſerve his ſiniſter commoditie, when he ought to lend to the poore to ſatisfie his neceſsitie,
ſuch thrift is a braunch of theft by the opinion of D. P. Martyr vpon the 2. Rom. and all his mony will but turne to his own miſery.

The Vſurer is taught generally in the word to lend, moſt eſpecially to his neighbour in the time of his neceſsity Syrac. 29. Hemingeus writing vpon this place, ſaith. Hic aperte ſapiens reſtringit mutuationis debitum ad neceſsitatis tempus. It is cō manded by Moſes, Thou ſhalt lend him ſufficient for his neede which he hath. Deut. 15.8. It is commended by David, The righteous is mercifull and lendeth Pſal. 112.5. It is imitated of the godly; I my breethren and ſervants (ſaith Nehemiah) doe lend them money and corne. Nehem. 5.10.

Sithens we ought eſpecially to lend to the poore, euen from the very nature of the law of lending it ſelfe, it were very neceſſary to diſtinguiſh the eſtates of men, that the poore man may be the better knowne, thereby to take away all colour of excuſe from the Vſurer.

div.head: A deſcription of ſome ſuch poore men as WE ARE COMMAVNDED TO lend vnto vvithout Vſurie.
div.p: THe begger that liveth of Almes, ſuch an one as is blind, lame, or having other defectes of nature, to this man we are preciſely inioyned to give & not properly ſaid to lend, vnleſſe it be to the Lord. He that hath mercy on the poore, lendeth to the Lord, Prov. 19. for he cannot reſtore that which he receive. Hereof ſaith the Preacher, Caſt thy bread vpon the waters. Eccl. 11.1. as a thing loſt, this is none of thoſe poore-men properly to whom the ſcripture willeth any great ſumme of mony to be lent, but otherwiſe to be relieved.

Theſe are to be noted
Artificers
Labourers
Husbandmen
Young mariedmen
in the number of the poore.

div.head: Artificers.
div.p: THe Artificer which hath nothing but his bare fingers and tooles to get his living reſpecting his charge is to be deemed a poore man: for as cunning without tooles can do nothing, ſo tooles without wherewith can not be ſet on work, and without worke the man ſhall ſoone begge, yet having worke he may live in want. To this man we muſt not only lend without vſurie, but (if we miſtruſt him) we muſt take ſuch a pledge as he may well ſpare: it appeareth ſo in Deuter. 24.10. Thou ſhalt not goe into his houſe to fetch his pledge, but thou ſhalt ſtand without, and the man that borrowed it of thee, ſhall bring the pledge out of the dores to thee. And this ſtandeth with great reaſon: for if a man ſhould take his tooles to pledge, he ſhall not ſave ſo much by borrowing as he ſhall looſe by his worke for want of his tooles.

div.head: Labourers.
div.p:
THe Labouring-man that hath neither houſe or home of his owne to hold his head in but liveth onely of his bare & bodily labour is to be accounted a poore man, whoſe neceſsitie is ſuch ſometime as he muſt needs borrow, and vpon ſuch a pledge as he cannot well forbeare, as his garment or ſuch like, therefore we muſt neither take vſurie of him nor deteine his pledge; for it is written, If it be a poore body thou ſhalt not ſleepe vvith his pledge, but ſhalt restore it when the Sunne goe
downe that he may ſleepe in his raiment. Deut. 24.12. Exod. 22.26. and it is an horrible thing to withold it, it is this that make the Prophet cry out againſt the Rich, They lie downe vpon clothes laide to pledge, Amos 2.8. & Iob deſcribing the impiety of the wicked ſaith, They take the pledge of the poore. Iob 24.9.

div.head: Husbandmen.
div.p: THe Husband-man that hath but a ſimple cottage of his owne and keepeth a beaſt or two upon the common to maintaine his charge, is to be eſteemed a poore man, whoſe eſtate is ſuch as miniſtreth occaſion to borow; to whom we ought to lend without vſurie, and yet we muſt not take his cattell for a pledge: for it is reprooved, You take the widovves Oxe to pledge. Iob. 24.23. leſt in ſo doing we ſooner impoveriſh then pleaſure him: and it is no more tollerable then to take the nether or the vpper milſtone to pledge. Deut. 24.6. for this gage is his living.

div.head: Young married men.
div.p:
THe Young married man that is bare to begin the world and wants wherwith to furniſh and follow his trade, is to be eſteemed a poore man: the originall of the cuſtome of money-mariages was made as a meane for the benefit of new beginners, to the end they might gather ſome ſtocke to ſet vp withall, (which offrings are now commonly abuſed amongſt the better ſort.) For this cauſe many godly men have giuē great
ſummes of mony to remaine as a ſtock for ever in the cities and townes where they dwelt, that it might be freely lent to benefit ſuch poore beginners, therefore Hemingeus noteth this to be one, to whom we ought to lend without vſurie.

Generally
He is to be deemed a poore-man which hath need to borrow and hath nothing that he may conveniently forbeare to make money of.
He is a rich-man (in reſpect of the other) that borroweth when he hath ſomwhat which he might very well ſpare to make money of.

To take Vſurie of theſe men or ſuch like whoſe poverty appeares either in our conſcience or acquaintance, it is a moſt odious act: for not only the word of God but all Writers do eſpecially condemne this. The places of Scripture are before expreſſed, the opinion of ſome auncient writers follow.
An crudelior eſt, ſaith S. Auguſtine: Is he more cruell that taketh any thing by force from the rich, then he which doth crucifie the poore with vſurie.
Nihil vſuris turpius. S. Chryſostom ſaith, there is no vſurie more filthy then that which is taken of the poore.
Vſuras quaerere, ſaith S. Ierome. To take Vſury of ſuch it is all one to deceive or drawe away by violence.
Sine ferro dimicat. S. Ambroſe to that effect ſaith he doth revenge him ſelfe without a ſword that taketh vſury.

div.head: A praemonition for poore men.
div.p:
AS you are deſirous to borrowe when you neede, ſo you muſt be carefull to pay when you borrow, although you
ought to pay no vſurie at all, yet I cannot finde in all the ſcriptures but that you ought to pay your debts. The Pſalmiſt ſaith, The wicked borrovveth and payeth not againe. Pſal. 37.21. the poore widow made a conſcience to pay her debts that had but a pitcher of oyle, for this cauſe the Prophet did increaſe her oile, and willed her firſt to go ſell ſome of it to pay her debts, & ſhee and her children to live of the reſt. 2. King. 1.2. there is now no fruition of the 7. yeere of freedome vnleſſe the Creditours of their conſcience will releaſe their debts.

div.head: The opinion of Writers concerning VSVRIE.
div.p: S. Barnard calleth vſurie, venenum patrimonij, the poyſon of a mans inheritance, he ſaith in another place, Quid eſt vſura legalis? latro praedicens quod intendit ſcilicet rapere. S. Chryſostome ſaith, that vſurie in his time was accompted an extreme impudencie. hom. 57.
S. Hierome ſaith, vſurie is a ſpeciall cry of ſedition.

S. Baſil vpon the 14. Pſalm. ſaith that vſurie have beene the meanes to bring many an one to the halter, his meaning is by paying vſurie they haue growen poore, and ſo fall aſtealing, and at laſt come to hanging.
Iuſtinius the Emperour in the civill law ſaith, that to take vſurie is to rob by order and ſufferance of law.
M. Beza ſaieth, Chriſtian charity forbiddeth a man to put forth mony to vſurie.
Biſh. Iuell ſaith, that vſurie hardeneth the heart: it is the curſe of God and the people.
S. Ambroſe vpon the 22. of Ezek. ſaith, See how the Prophet hath coupled Idolatry and Vſurie together that one might counterpoiſe the other in euill.
Pomerianus ſaith, that vſurie is the preſent poyſon of the Church and common-wealth.
Muſculus ſaith, graunt vſury and then take away the law of loue: he tearmes it in another place, the fire of Vſurie as a thing that conſumes.
Lactantius ſaith, let a Chriſtian take this courſe, that in lending he take no vſurie, for that is againſt the law of lending. lib. 6. cap. 18.

Vnaprincipalis ratio Bartholomei Sepolitani. againſt vſurie, if a man ſhould pay for that he borrow, he ſhould give increaſe for his owne, for he that lendeth doth transferre the dominion and the vſe together.
Melancthon doeth alledge the like reaſon, lending to Vſury fighteth with aequalitie: for the rule of aequality ſaith it is not lawfull to make againe of another mans goods.
Luther complained in his time that Vſurie had overthrowen whole countries.
The auncient Romans for a time abhorred Vſurie as a ſpeciall enormitie, but after they gave entertainment to it, it turned to to their deſtruction. Hem.
Egypt was overwhelmed with vſury, and ſo were the Iarmyns.
The Perſians abſtaine it as a practiſe of lying and deceit.
The Indians can not abide it, nor the French-men.
The Engliſh-men have loathed it as Chronicles record before the Danes and Saxons.
Moſt countries haue contemned vſury, as a thing very odious and againſt nature, therefore many which were led but by the light of nature haue inveyed againſt it.

Ariſtotle ſaieth, that vſury is againſt nature: his reaſon is
this, Pecunia natura non poteſt parere ergo vſuram expecunia capere pugnat cum natura.
Plutarcke ſaith, that it is againſt nature to take vſurie, for this cauſe Ex nihilo nihil fit.
Alphon ſus ſaith, that vſurie is the very death of nature.
Cato beeing demanded what it was to take vſurie, anſwered, Quid hominem occidere?

Plato made a law, that he which tooke vſurie, he ſhould loſe both the principall and the vſurie. And for that it was ſo execrable, he did expell all vſurie out of his common-wealth. in quinto de legibus.

I could repeate many others to this effect, but we may perceiue how vſurie hath beene eſteemed by theſe; although it be a principle in reaſon, that the practiſe beeing ill reputed of, the practitioner can haue no better, yet it ſhall not be amiſſe to ſet forth the diſcredible account hath beene made of Vſurers in moſt ages and times.

div.head: How Ʋſurers haue beene accounted of.
div.p: HEmingeus beeing a boy, ſaith he could not remember aboue 2. knowne Vſurers in the lande he liued in, they flouriſhed a while, but their children after them came to pouertie and reproch, ſo true is that verſe,
div.q: Ex male quaeſitis non gaudet tertius haeres.
div.p: In the 12. Centuries 4 chap. it is reported by thoſe that wrote that eccleſiaſticall Storie, that there was not an Vſurer to be found in all the countrey, and if an vſurer came to be knowne, his houſes were called the deuils houſes, his fields the deuils croppe, &c.

Brunnion preaching vpon a time to his people in the preſence of ſome vſurers; he demanded if any vſurer were preſent, not an vſurer would ſpeake: inſomuch as he asked if any Scavinger were there: a Scavinger made anſwer he was one: hereupon the preacher ſaid, the ſcauinger was of better account then the vſurer: for the Scavinger was not aſhamed to heare and anſwer to his name and title when he was called, but the vſurer was.

The Vſurers are aſhamed at this day of their title, more then other men: ſome write themſelues gentlemen, merchants: others, grocers, mercers, but they will not write themſelues Vſurers: for indeede they are aſhamed of the name and word of vſurie, and therefore they haue got theſe fine tearmes: they will not ſay, let their money to vſurie; but to intereſt, or put it to vſans, or they take conſideration, rent, or an honourable rewarde. If they did thinke well of vſurie, they would neuer cloake it vnder other contracts.
Dauid praying againſt his enemies, Pſal. 99. wiſheth them this plague, Let the extortioner take all his goods. The Septuaginta, Pagne, Tremellius and Iunius tranſlate this word extortioner, Vſurer.

Muſculus commenting vpon the ſame place ſaith, ſee howe Dauid praies that his enemies might light in the vſurers hands; noting thereby what a curſe it was to goe to an vſurer, and howe the vſurer was the meanes to convey the ſame curſe to others.
The Prophet Amos chap. 8. cryeth out againſt ſuch as ſolde the poore for old ſhoes. Gualter writing vpon that place ſaith, it is common to all, but ſpecially to the vſurers.

S. Ambroſe complained in his time, that by the meanes of vſurers, parents were inforced to ſet forth their children to ſale, or binde them to captiuitie, for the payment of their debts, and
yet neuer came to poſſeſſe their inheritance.
Luther reports that Caeſar commāded that an vſurer ſhould not be counted and iudged by law an honeſt perſon.
M. Calvin ſaith, it is rare to ſee an honeſt man and an vſurer.
Baldus ſaith, an vſurer is a defamed perſon, and ſhall not enioy ſuch goods as are giuen him.
Hemingeus ſaith, the vſurer might not make an offering at the altar, neither was he preferred to dignitie or called to offices.
Thoſe which trauell the low Countries ſay the vſurer is ſo baſely accounted of, that no man will be in his companie, and you ſhall ſooner get one to goe to a brothel-houſe then to an vſurers houſe.
The celebration of a maſſe would neuer ſuffer the vſurer to kiſſe the paxe; none would fetch fire at an vſurers houſe; the boyes wondred and all men hiſt at an vſurer.
A thiefe was better eſteemed then an vſurer: for a thiefe was to make but double reſtitution, the vſurer quadruple. Heming. Iac. 5.
Licurgus would not ſuffer an vſurer to dwell in Sparta, nor Plato any to dwell in Graecia.
If the Scripture willeth vs to ſhunne things of ill report, what account ſhall we make of an vſurer that hath ſo bad a report.

div.head: Epiphonema.
div.p:
WHether we are to regard in theſe Writers, the time, becauſe it is many yeres ſince ſome of them wrote; or the place, becauſe moſt are forrain writers, where the
generation of the Iewes are hardly rooted out; or any ſuch like circumſtances. Certes I would not wiſh the Vſurer to ſtand vpon ſuch cauils, but ſeeing not onely the word of God, but all ages, nations, lawes, and ſects of perſons doe condemne vſurie as a ſinne moſt odious and opprobrious, I would haue him obſerue that ſame faſt in Eſay 58.6. to looſe the bonds of wickednes. S. Hierome writing vpon that place, vnderſtands by it the extreame bonds that Vſurers wrappe others in, So getting his goods in the feare of God, they will be to his comfort while he liueth, & without pricke to his conſcience when he dieth.
